articles.headline: Moderate Islamist Party Heads Toward Victory in Tunisia
articles.snippet: Ennahda began talks to form a unity government with a coalition of liberals in a rare alliance that party leaders hailed as a model for other Arab countries.
articles.abstract: Ennahda began talks to form a unity government with a coalition of liberals in a rare alliance that party leaders hailed as a model for other Arab countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s moderate Islamist political party emerged Monday as the acknowledged leader in elections for a constitutional assembly and began talks to form a unity government with a coalition of liberals in a rare alliance that party leaders hailed as an inclusive model for countries emerging from the tumult of the Arab Spring.

articles.headline: New Unease for Europe’s Rescue Plan
articles.snippet: Fears are growing that the latest rescue will be another minimal step that falls short of a solution.
articles.abstract: Fears are growing that the latest rescue will be another minimal step that falls short of a solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As officials worked on Monday to iron out details of a plan to solve the European debt crisis, fears were growing that the result might be another example of European leaders doing less rather than more. And concerns are that it may not be enough.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: How Netflix Lost 800,000 Members, and Good Will
articles.snippet: Reed Hastings, the chief executive, talks about the missteps that cost subscribers and sent the stock plunging.
articles.abstract: Reed Hastings, the chief executive, talks about the missteps that cost subscribers and sent the stock plunging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reed Hastings was soaking in a hot tub with a friend last month when he shared a secret: his company, Netflix, was about to announce a plan to divide its movie rental service into two — one offering streaming movies over the Internet, the other offering old-fashioned DVDs in the mail.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Lectern Gone, Romney Finds More Success
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has shed much of the operational and psychological baggage that weighed down his maiden campaign.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has shed much of the operational and psychological baggage that weighed down his maiden campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mitt Romney crammed for the Republican presidential debates four years ago, he went all out: The campaign built a stage with four lecterns and used senior staff members as stand-ins for his rivals, John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani. A room packed with highly paid media consultants and senior officials barked suggestions as they flipped through a white binder filled with policy positions. Over time, one aide said, the binder grew to resemble the Manhattan White Pages.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Acquisitions at Olympus Scrutinized
articles.snippet: A tale of well-connected advisers and puzzling deals.
articles.abstract: A tale of well-connected advisers and puzzling deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Even as the F.B.I. in the United States investigates exorbitant advisory fees that the Japanese company Olympus paid to a firm with links to the Cayman Islands, a second set of deals is drawing scrutiny here in Japan.

articles.headline: In Cautious Times, Banks Flooded With Cash
articles.snippet: With fewer attractive lending and investment options, it is harder for banks to make a healthy profit from the enormous amount in deposits.
articles.abstract: With fewer attractive lending and investment options, it is harder for banks to make a healthy profit from the enormous amount in deposits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bankers have an odd-sounding problem these days: they are awash in cash.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: U.S. Agencies Infiltrating Drug Cartels Across Mexico
articles.snippet: Networks of informants have helped capture or kill about two dozen high and midlevel drug traffickers, and sometimes given American agents access to the top cartel leaders.
articles.abstract: Networks of informants have helped capture or kill about two dozen high and midlevel drug traffickers, and sometimes given American agents access to the top cartel leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American law enforcement agencies have significantly built up networks of Mexican informants that have allowed them to secretly infiltrate some of that country’s most powerful and dangerous criminal organizations, according to security officials on both sides of the border.

articles.headline: Outside Cleveland, Snapshots of Poverty’s Surge in the Suburbs
articles.snippet: The poor population in America’s suburbs rose 53 percent last decade, double the 26 percent increase in cities, confronting communities with unaccustomed challenges.
articles.abstract: The poor population in America’s suburbs rose 53 percent last decade, double the 26 percent increase in cities, confronting communities with unaccustomed challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARMA HEIGHTS, Ohio — The poor population in America’s suburbs — long a symbol of a stable and prosperous American middle class — rose by more than half after 2000, forcing suburban communities across the country to re-evaluate their identities and how they serve their populations.

articles.headline: Banks Face Pressure on Eve of Meeting on Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: A day before a crucial meeting of European leaders, officials were trying to persuade banks to accept much deeper losses on their holdings of Greek debt.
articles.abstract: A day before a crucial meeting of European leaders, officials were trying to persuade banks to accept much deeper losses on their holdings of Greek debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European officials scrambled on Tuesday for a way to entice banks to accept much deeper losses on their Greek bonds as debt crisis talks went down to the wire before a crucial gathering of European leaders on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Jack Ewing
